caption_original: Today, we will be hiking through the bush to get some drill cores — samples of a natural material previously removed using a cylinder drill. While at the core storage area, we take samples and measurements from the drill core to get information about the subsurface. Sometimes the drill core is only accessible by overgrown roads, so it can be quite the journey tracking it down!

caption_original: Hi everyone, and welcome to my summer home! It’s geophysicist Vicki Tschirhart here! My field site is located in the Patterson Lake corridor, southwestern Athabasca Basin, a region known for its uranium deposits. Our multidisciplinary field party includes geochemists, geochronologists, geophysicists and geologists, eerts who have the collective goal of understanding how and why these deposits formed.

caption_original: Student research assistants Nicolas Piette-Lauziere and Zoik Brault are in the field at the edge of Cape Breton Highlands National Park. They are proudly displaying their commemorative t-shirts! Over the last month, Nicolas and Zoik have been mapping a fault zone on Cape Breton Island that separates rocks with different geological histories on either side. By studying the fault zone in the field, and collecting samples to study in the lab, Nicolas hopes to discover when and why it formed, and how it may have created a pathway for magma deep in the Earth’s crust to rise and form granite.

caption_original: Kathryn Bethune is a Professor of Geology at the University of Regina. She and her Ph.D. student, Dillon Johnstone, are investigating the regional setting and related structural controls of uranium deposits in the area. The primary aim is to create a fuller -D and -D picture of the major structural features and their relationship to the uranium deposits, as well as getting a fuller understanding of the sequence and timing of structures.

caption_original: Meet Jeremy! My colleague Jeremy Powell is interested in the low-temperature history of southern Athabasca. He’s combing the drill core for fractures and faults, using many different techniques to understand when these structures were active. Dating the movement of these structures and the timing of hydrothermal fluids that circulated through them will help us learn how and when these uranium deposits formed.

caption_original: “What will Canada’s energy picture look like in the year ?” Looking beyond their current work and eertise, participants of the Generation Energy roundtable at Dalhousie University were asked for their vision of Canada’s future energy mix. A diverse group — students, academics, Indigenous representatives, energy consultants, members of civil society — they had plenty of insights ready for Natural Resources Canada’s Minister, Jim Carr. Dal graduate Samantha Peverell provided her thoughts: “GenEnergy isn’t just about generating energy — it’s about saving energy, too.”

caption_original: Meet Eric Potter, a fellow research scientist at the GSC. Eric studies how and why these uranium deposits formed. For this project, Eric is looking for ancient chemical fingerprints of fluids that formed these deposits. This research is attempting to create a way of identifying faults that channeled the uranium-bearing fluids to the site of the deposit and addressing questions on how the deposits form.

caption_original: Here’s another innovation that was featured at the forum.This is the EnCurrent hydrokinetic turbine.This turbine is ideal for power generation in remote communities. A kW version of this turbine is being installed in the Sagkeeng First Nation Community on the Winnipeg River; kW could charge a medium-sized home or business. This installation also gives NRCan a chance to monitor the performance of the turbine. These turbines have also been installed elsewhere in Canada, the U.S. and India.

caption_original: – Canadian innovation was showcased during the forum. This battery-powered Eco-Marathon car was designed by , a group of engineering students at the University of Manitoba. The Eco-Marathon competition challenges students to design and build cars to see which vehicle can travel the farthest distance on a single litre of fuel. caption_original: What will it take to fight ? A team of the best clean energy “nerds” in Canada! One self-proclaimed “GHG nerd” is Anamika, who was profiled as part of the initiative. Visit for more information.
